content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the appointment of a Director of National Transportation Research. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Federal investment in transportation research is only about 1% of overall government spending on transportation programs, despite a 40% increase in funding for transportation programs in the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century. Funding for transportation research and development has remained relatively flat, with inadequate resources devoted to long-term goals. Competitive, peer-reviewed awards are best for addressing strategic research needs, but the diversity of research programs poses challenges for effective centers. To ensure the United States transportation system meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals, increasing Federal investment in long-range planning and supporting competitive research into systemic transportation issues is crucial. The Department of Transportation aims to better coordinate research and development programs, foster data interchange, and establish nationwide priorities in transportation research. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The Center's duties include coordinating research and development programs, fostering data interchange, and establishing nationwide priorities in transportation research. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is tasked with developing a long-term national policy for promoting research and development in multimodal transportation. It will support projects with long-term significance and clear public benefits where private investment is not optimal. The National Center for Transportation Solutions awards grants to research institutions for long-term transportation objectives and facilitates data interchange among interested parties in the United States. The National Center for Transportation Solutions in the United States consults with officials from the Department of Transportation, coordinates research programs with public and private groups, evaluates government research programs, and submits annual reports to Congress on activities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions submits an annual report to Congress on activities and recommendations for research and development in multimodal transportation. The National Center for Transportation Solutions submits an annual report to Congress on activities and recommendations for research and development in multimodal transportation. SEC. 5. NATIONAL CENTER FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS BOARD. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members appointed by various authorities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by different authorities, including consultation with key Senate and House leaders. Board members must represent various professions, regions of the US, and possess relevant skills and experience. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members must have skills and experience suitable for their roles. Initial appointments should be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving 6-year terms, limited to two consecutive terms. Terms are staggered for continuity. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members are appointed with staggered terms: six members for six years, five members for four years, and five members for two years. Terms do not expire during election years. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members have staggered terms, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Board of the National Center for Transportation Solutions shall hold its first meeting upon all members being appointed. Meetings will be called by the Chair, with a majority of members constituting a quorum. The Board will select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members, serving 2-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms as Chairman. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, carries out its authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board for a six-year term. The Director of National Transportation Research serves for a six-year term and their salary is capped at the rate payable for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. ORGANIZATION OF CENTER. The Center shall be organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division shall have a committee for recommendations and consultation. Each division committee, composed of at least five members, advises the Board and Director on division issues. Members serve two-year terms and elect a Chairman annually. Committees set their own procedures within restrictions. Each division committee advises the Board and Director on division issues, setting its own procedures within restrictions. SEC. 8. POWERS OF CENTER. The Board and division committees have the authority to conduct hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, and receive necessary information to carry out the Act. The Board and division committees have the authority to enter contracts, use postal services, and accept gifts to carry out the purposes of the Act. The Center may publish research results and dispose of gifts or donations. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director has the authority to appoint and terminate staff for the Center without following civil service laws. The staff is responsible for submitting strategic and annual plans, as well as developing an annual budget for the Center. The Director appoints staff for the Center and is responsible for developing an annual budget. They administer programs, provide staff support to the Board, report on program progress, and coordinate with relevant organizations. The Director appoints staff for the Center, develops an annual budget, administers programs, provides staff support to the Board, reports on program progress, and coordinates with relevant organizations. The Director may fix compensation for Center personnel without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement. The Director may appoint staff, develop budgets, administer programs, provide staff support to the Board, and coordinate with organizations. Employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement, maintain civil service status, and receive volunteer services for activities. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured at specified rates. The Director can appoint staff, develop budgets, administer programs, provide staff support to the Board, and coordinate with organizations. Employees can receive volunteer services for activities without regard to section 1342 of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director will award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States by September 30, 2005. These centers will conduct research on long-term multimodal transportation issues with clear public benefits and where private investment is necessary due to market failures or distortions. The northeast regional center established under this section will be located in a State with high traffic congestion levels and will focus on conducting research on long-term multimodal transportation issues with public benefits and private investment needs due to market failures or distortions. State (2) is among the top 10 states with high traffic congestion levels in the United States, based on the ratio of urban National Highway System roads to urban National Highway System lane miles. SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010 are as follows: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
